data.text: The single greatest productivity tip I could give is to wake up an hour earlier and get straight to work on the single most important thing that will move the needle toward your goals. Preferably before most people are even awake. People are the biggest source of distractions.

Competition is largely an illusion. 95% of people don't even try to do great things. 0.1% of the people are loud, so you overestimate how many people there are. The rest get stuck worrying about competition and quitting after 2 weeks.

If you're young, I don't think you understand how much of an advantage you have. When I talk with various leaders, CEOs, etc, they're absolutely clueless when it comes to social media and technology. They pay an absurd amount of money for young people to help them. By simply

Discipline is about getting clear on what you want. Once you know with absolute conviction that you don't want the life that your current habits are leading to, you hate the thought of doing them. Staying the same becomes more painful than pursuing an uncertain goal.
Your potential is determined by how much uncertainty you're willing to embrace.
More in yesterdays letter: https://t.co/ttlxKYC2yi

data.text: Don't identify with a tool because tools change and get replaced. Identify with what the tools allow you to do: create. That's what you love doing. It doesn't matter if you do it with a paintbrush, camera, Photoshop, or AI. What matters is the vision you bring into reality.

Discipline is a feature of identity.

Meaning, you are already disciplined based on what you view as important. Some people play 12 hours of video games, others have no issue eating healthy and going to the gym.

Discipline isn't forced, it's native to who you are.

One of the best things you can do for your future is learn "how to think."

Money, relationships, or anything else you can do in life are dependent on how well you think.

data.text: You as a single person have more power today than a 20 person company of the past. The internet gave you the ability to learn anything. Social media gave you the leverage to reach anyone. AI is giving you the ability to create almost anything. Please don't waste it.

Feeling lost is a sign that you are no longer your past self, but not fully the person you want to become. That's uncomfortable. The worst thing you can do here is what most people do, which is to numb the pain with comfort and close yourself off to your future self.

The reason you're not happy is because you think happiness = euphoria so if you aren't maxing out on dopamine all the time you think you're doing something wrong.

Happiness, most of the time, is being calm and in a good mood.

Focus on 2 things:

- Mastering your mental / emotional state in situations you can't control

- Realizing you can control more than you think, and that you can improve your skill to the point of getting what you want

Give it 10 years and watch everything change
Learn how here: https://t.co/MXcBesy48E

data.text: One of the most important things you can understand is that school trains you to learn a specific way, and that way is extremely slow. Learning allows you to be useful and get what you want. It should be a top priority to learn how to learn, practice it, and master it.

As much as people want to argue that physical appearance doesn’t matter, it does. A lot. It’s 24/7 non-verbal communication of your values.

Most people aren’t unattractive, they just don’t put a shred of effort into taking care of themselves.

You can learn anything in 2 weeks.

If you can't, you're trying to learn too much at once. Break the goal down and focus solely on doing what's necessary to reach it. If your learning doesn't involve doing, most of what you learn is disappearing the second you learn it.

If you're trying to get exposure on your work, it sounds weird, but starting a podcast is one of the best things you can do.

Not because you want to make it the number 1 podcast in the world, but because:

1) High status people / people you respect would rather be on a podcast
Everyone wants a great story to tell (but not the catastrophic failure that makes it worth telling).

Your work is unlikely to be noticed until your skill matches your taste. You know what “good” looks like, but you need to practice until what you produce is at that level. That’s when things take off.

I hate the whole "entrepreneurship isn't for everyone" narrative because "it's a hard thing to do." No shit it's hard. That's the point. Yes, most people aren't cut out for it right at this very second. But people can grow. They can learn something new. They can, in fact,

If you want to achieve anything great, it needs to become your one true priority. The only thing on your mind. Nobody accidently got rich. Nobody accidently built a great physique. They were obsessed with it for multiple years until they no longer had to think about it.

For those who need to hear it: getting rich is a perfectly viable goal. People who have a poor relationship with money will try to convince you that it isn't a meaningful way to live, but that couldn't be further from the truth. You can do great things and make great money.

The fact that most people turn 23 and repeat the same 6 months for the rest of their life scared the shit out of me to the point where I would do anything to avoid that. Same city. Same bars. Same problems. They call it "living life" when it is the complete opposite.

Money is a skill that can be learned just like playing a video game, but since it's become so intertwined with status, self-worth, morality, and survival people have such a distorted view of it.

Your parents tell you to save it.

Your pastor tells you to avoid it.

Your culture

How to figure out what you want:

1) Make a guess at what you want

2) Do everything in your power to achieve it

3) Realize that everything you did was just a prototype

4) Start over with more clarity on what you want

Then repeat steps 2 through 4.

Probably for the rest of

It's painful to watch young people treat youth as a currency rather than investment capital. The time, energy, and focus you have when you're young are extremely valuable and disappear fast. You're forming habits that will come back and hit you like a truck when you turn 30.

Be careful listening to anyone who doesn’t have the life you want. Those people are rare. 1% of the population. The other 99% will blabber about how you should live your life when they’ve wasted their own. I'm sure they're kind people, but they have no idea what's best for you.

The best way to make the most of your 20s is to make them your worst.

Because if we're being honest, most people hit a small peak and then repeat the same 6 months over and over again.

Here are 3 things to avoid and 3 things to do:
https://t.co/q7VbvVr31J
Your mind expands to fill the goals set for achievement.

You're going to miss out on 99% of the experiences life has to offer. That's just how it is.

In other words, you're not missing out on anything by focusing on a few important things.

There is always more that can be done.

Lost people can't figure out what to do. Drained people try to do it all. Happy people choose a few things they deeply care about and dedicate the entirety of their mental, physical, and financial energy toward that.

Life is hard because you don't know what you want. That's 90% of the battle. Once you have extreme clarity on what you want, after 5-10 calculated risks, everything else is quite simple. If you can reach that before you turn 25, you're in the top 1%.

You need to believe you are better than most people.

Not because you’re superior to them, but because what most people create isn’t that good.

If you don’t believe that you can create something at least slightly better than what is already out there – the product, the app, the
Why do people who wasted their life always have the most to say about how you should live yours

4 habits.

data.text: You're always tired because you don't have a purpose, or your purpose is to complete some meaningless set of tasks that lead to a paycheck. You can sleep for 8 hours and cut out every food imaginable, but if you don't have a life trajectory you deeply care about, you will never

Your life is determined by a series of 10-12 bold decisions to shift the trajectory you were given by your parents and teachers.

If you don’t, you stall out. You wake up 10 years later wondering why your life got worse even though you’ve done everything you were told to do.

The best decisions you will make are the ones that everyone else will say are stupid, risky, or crazy. And they’re right. To normal people, they are, but that’s exactly why you’re doing it. You deeply understand that it’s the only way to never end up like them.

Every morning is a chance to choose what you suffer for.

I wrote about this in depth.

data.text: You're bored because you haven't developed a skill set that allows you to take on interesting challenges.

Grab a notebook.

Write out exactly what you want in your future, don't miss a detail. Then, break it down into goals. Decades, years, months, weeks, and days.

Every day, write down the 3 levers you can move to create your vision.

Then, forget about the goals and execute.

Get excited over the small things. The bland but healthy food. The difficult but rewarding last rep. The uncomfortable but necessary silence of being alone. All of it.

The highs, lows, bigs, and smalls of life are going to pass whether you enjoy them or not.

Being able to figure it out is becoming more important than ever:

https://t.co/wNxZtCx9f0

Read last weeks letter^ https://t.co/lj1RLY4jPH

Cope:

"I can't do that."

Curiosity:

"Why can't I do that?"

Conviction:

"Fuck it I'll figure it out."

It can be as simple as 4 habits.

One for mind. One for body. One for finances. One for relationships.

Choose a habit for each that gets 80% of the results with 20% of the effort.

Stick with them for a year and you'll be ahead of most people.

As a creator who doesn't like AI doing all of your writing, scripting, idea generation, what has been the most useful AI workflow you've come across?

I see the value in businesses having all of that done for them, but for "idea workers" so to say, what have you found?

How to be productive as fuck:

- Find something you deeply care about
- Do everything in your power to do that full time
- Say no to anything that pulls you away from those

Most people use deep work tactics to compensate for a lack of work they can't pull themselves away from.

If you have multiple interests, this is for you.

https://t.co/zcothtS5Hn

Read here^ https://t.co/Sec5dDxI4w

If you struggle with topics to write about, or you don't know which niche to choose:

Try creating a mission instead.

An ideal life you are leading people towards.

Then, almost any idea can be framed to help move toward that end goal.

I wrote a post on this:
It's better to have conviction in a bad idea and fail than to nuance yourself into irrelevance.

If you want to grow fast, you need to create something so undeniably good that people with good taste share it without second thought. Forget about the algorithm for a bit. Smart people love to share high-signal things on socials and in tight-knit group chats. Optimize for that.
Spill your mind onto the internet for a year and see where it takes you.

The next 10 years will be insane.

Nobody knows what's going to happen.

Work will change. People will feel lost. It's inevitable.

But there are a few things you can do to prepare:
https://t.co/NPOtrbpxq5

The minute I become too frugal or money conscious is the moment it starts to control me and becomes difficult to make. When I spend almost carelessly, it seems to find its way back. A poor psychological relationship with money will ruin you.

If you want to have great ideas, surround yourself with people who have great ideas. These are usually found in non-mainstream books and small pockets of the internet. Once it hits mainstream it gets tainted.

You don't need an insane sales funnel.

You need to build a world. A small-scale Marvel with movies (long form), shows (short form), and action figures (products) for people to binge and explore.

Posting for 2 weeks then giving up doesn't give people a chance to trust you.

You aren't passionate about the skill.

You're passionate about creating things.

Skills change as technology accelerates. Don't latch onto them. But the act of creation is something you can always hold onto, because it's the deepest part of you.

Find something you're deeply excited about.

Obsess over it. Rip it apart, study it, and put it back together, but in your own way. Share it where billions of people hang out. Get one person to care about it as much as you do. Then five. Then a thousand. Then you're set.

Here's a short future-proof manifesto:

https://t.co/hEVfI62sJP

Read here^ https://t.co/pIRFGQFl9I

The safer you try to be, the more vulnerable you become, because you don't create that safety. You seek certainty in a job, a belief system, a nice little path someone else has laid out for you.

A good life stems from how much uncertainty you're willing to embrace.

How to future-proof yourself:

- Act without permission
- Share your work in public
- Make as many mistakes as possible
- Get really fucking good at what you do
- Learn AI by trying to automate yourself out of work
- Deeply embody that any and all problems can be solved

It doesn’t matter how hard you worked.

You can write for 10 years straight, but that doesn’t mean anyone will care about your writing.

I don’t care how much you “just want to write” and how everyone else has bad taste but you. Writing is a two-player game. 80% of your success
Your life isn’t good because you’ve spent years learning skills to advance your career, but you haven’t spent a day learning how to live. They are completely different things.

Here's my deep work philosophy:
https://t.co/DmDhIkG61L
The only real safety net in today's world is a body of work that's impossible to ignore.

Being productive and being creative are two entirely different states.

Productivity demands narrow focus, order, deadlines, urgency, stress.

Creativity demands an open mind, the right amount of chaos, and a lack of focus on outcomes.

They work together for the best results.

Stop trying to figure out what you want.

When your mind is lost, stressed, or turbulent, it's extremely difficult to imagine a clear future.

Do this instead:
https://t.co/pfn1ZcVuue

A trend I see coming soon:

Creators sharing AI prompts along with their posts, videos, newsletters, or even courses because it adds an interactive layer.

The problem with content is that it's static.

The teachings may be valuable, but since they don't account for your own mind

Your mind runs on a storyline.

Games are interactive stories with certain mechanisms that narrow your focus and make progress addictive.

If you want to get unstuck, use this AI prompt to turn your life into a video game (it's long):

–––

You are LifeQuest AI, a strategic life

One of the most beneficial things to spend your time on is transcending the fear response that you're programmed to have. You aren't fighting a bear. You're sitting down to type at a computer. You're not in danger and it isn't a threat to try something new with your life.

Your actions reflect your goals.

But most people aren't conscious of the goal their mind is trying to achieve. They don't realize that they are unconsciously choosing the very life they claim to hate.

You may say you want success, but your actions show that you want to avoid
The most disciplined people I know have a negative outcome that sents rent free in their mind and fuels them to work in the opposite direction even if they don't feel like it.

It doesn't matter if it takes years.

What the fuck else are you going to do?

You aren't going to learn, build, experiment, and everything that makes life enjoyable because you have something better to be doing?

Snap out of it.
Most people quit because they don't realize that 2-3 months of feeling like you have no idea what you're doing is a feature not a bug.
The secret you're looking for is found in the experience you gain by not looking for secrets.

Most people are addicted to being busy.

Not because it leads to the life they want, but because it's the new status symbol.

If you don't grind all day, you will stay broke and never make it (when the reality is quite the opposite):
https://t.co/816O1C6jxH
Your life gains purpose when you deliberately choose who and what deserves your attention rather than handing it out to anything that gives you a bit of dopamine.
Only about ten people in your life genuinely care about you because we aren't wired to care for more than a small tribe's worth of people. Focus your energy on those people.

You don't know what you want to do with your life because you don't treat your life like a video game:
https://t.co/gWQqAO02u1

You can either build a strong mind through the hardships of doing nothing with your life or through the hardships of doing something with your life, but at least the second option makes life fun, lucrative, and interesting along the way.

The difference between greatness and mediocrity is the difference between doing what you want while correcting mistakes and doing what you want while not even being aware that you made a mistake because you don't have goals that the mistakes prevent you from achieving.

Everything worthwhile in life is deeply counterintuitive.

The things that seem most logical to the average mind are often the exact opposite of what actually works.

This is why doing the opposite of what most people do is often the quickest path to the results you want.
If you need to force yourself to work, you're working on the wrong thing.

Prioritize self-reliance.

For the first time in history people have an overwhelming amount of choices, and that will ruin the people who are dependent on being told what to learn, what to do, and who do it for without caring about why they're doing it in the first place.

If you're good at your job, your boss will give you more work.

If you answer emails fast, people email you more because you seem available.

If you're effective at what you do, guard your time because people will fill it up as much as they can.

Act busy but don't be busy.

The best way to use AI as a beginner is to get unstuck.

Ask it to teach you what to do next for a project, reveal gaps in your thinking, etc.

You learn the most when your mind is ready to apply the information to a problem.

The accelerated progress is nice too.

Give yourself permission to let your life get worse before it gets better. Most people are trapped in limbo because they don't know what goal to pursue, but when you've experienced the negative outcome firsthand, the goal becomes clear and you can't help but work toward it.

How I've been using AI to enhance my thinking:

- Find 3-5 thinkers I admire
- Have AI break down their core ideas, beliefs, and worldview
- Save results in documents to reference later

Then, I can ask my "tribe of mentors" to share their perspective on any problem or situation.

5AM alarms and cold showers are great.

But they don't get to the root of why your life feels terrible.

Here's a video to change the structure of your thinking (so you achieve higher forms of success):
https://t.co/0t385LgNqx

Self-confidence comes in 2 parts:

1) Convincing your mind to see a different perspective that makes self-doubt seem irrational.

2) Doing the uncomfortable thing over and over again until you realize it wasn't that uncomfortable in the first place.

Most people aren't as original as you think they are. They're just reading little-known books, having nuanced conversations, and giving themselves time to think. They are brutally aware that being stuck on their phone and doing busy work all day ruins the quality of your mind.
The fastest path to making better choices is to think about your ideal life before every single decision you make until it becomes a habit.

I feel like AI's impact on writing is vastly overhyped.

And that's coming from someone building an AI writing software.

First, there is already too much content. We can't read it all. AI will add more, but most of it will go to the bottom of the barrel unless written by someone

There are infinite different ways to think about a situation. Meaning, if you feel stuck, overwhelmed, or anxious, you're probably thinking from a sub-optimal perspective and can't "see" a way to get yourself out.

Even worse, most people have a worldview so deeply conditioned

If you want non-self-help books that will fundamentally change how you think about the world, people, and everything else in your life, read:

- Spiral Dynamics
- The Evolving Self
- Sex, Ecology, and Spirituality

Study them for a year and you will think on a much deeper level.

Reason to read:

Most of your ideas are triggered by other people’s ideas.

You have thousands of dormant ideas waiting to present themselves and reading is a great way to activate ideas you forgot about or didn’t know you had.

This vid will bump us over 1 million subs then I can finally release my second book (free PDF version along with it)

Subtle reminder that you're supposed to feel overwhelmed.

It means you're doing something new. You're taking a new path. You're learning. Growing. You branched into the unknown. It will be frustrating. You will feel lost. It will be painful, but staying the same is even worse.

Good things happen to people who understand that through deliberate and persistent practice, the bursts of progress will inevitably come, even if it feels like you are stuck spinning your wheels for months or years at a time.

If you don't shamelessly promote your work, every day for the next 10-20 years, you will get stuck doing someone else's work until you realize that nobody is going to pay you if they have no idea who you are.

How people think learning works:

You make linear progress, every time you study and practice you get better.

How learning actually works:

Long and frustrating plateaus followed by bursts of progress where everything clicks.

Learn to enjoy the periods where you feel stuck.

One of the most difficult yet life changing skills to develop is knowing when to drop everything and execute on idea as fast as possible. Quick and accurate decision making. No hesitation. No ego. Pure flow state to make it happen.

The best skill to learn is any skill paired with a personality that values agency, adaptability, learning, persistence, iteration, and creating something that not only you enjoy, but something others can't live without.

Every single post, book, video, or conversation you consume changes your mental DNA which goes on to influence the decisions you make and how good or bad your life is.

You become what you consume, but most don't care because it takes 2-3 years for the damage to really show.
A clear vision + daily learning + daily building + persistence & iteration = how you achieve anything you want.
Anything worth doing with your life takes about 1 year of deliberate practice 3+ times a week to even consider yourself decent at that thing. 5 years to be good. 10 years to be great.
If you hesitate on an idea it dies and will almost never be found again.

People get stuck because they let limiting beliefs take control of their mind as they age that convince them they can’t do difficult things, even when they’ve learned something as complex as speaking English, which is as difficult as playing something like Beethoven on the piano.

Thank you for reading.

This overlaps with the Protege Effect which is, in summary, that the teacher learns more than the student.

5) Write To Systematically Reflect On What You Learn

The Feynman Technique is a learning method popularized by physicist Richard Feynman.

It's about deeply understanding a concept by explaining it in simple terms as if you were teaching it to someone with no prior knowledge:

The best way to structure your learning is in 3 timeblocks

• 30-90 minutes of building the project
• 30-60 minutes of learning what you need
• 30 minutes of walking to reflect and process

Those are your keystone habits.

Do them every day. Do not skip.

4) Have AI Create A Study Regimen

Now that you have a frame of reference, project outline, and have started making progress—you can start supplementing with general learning and tutorials.

Create a new AI chat and try this prompt: https://t.co/jW2j5fpMGd
You can take this even further and hack your brain to be motivated to work before you even start working: https://t.co/tVIGujLweK

3.5) How To Start When You Don't Feel Like It

The Zeigarnik Effect is a psychological phenomenon where people remember unfinished tasks more than completed tasks.

Meaning, if we don't finish tasks for our project, it's much easier to find the motivation to get started.

annotations.normalized_text: How To Start When You Don't Feel Like It

data.text:
Now, AI is replacing that skill.

If you can write a prompt that gets you the information you need, fast, you can overcome obstacles and learn that much faster.

Whenever you have a question, even if it's "how do I select an object in Photoshop," ask AI.

Then, follow this process:

• You don't know what to do
• You try and fail
• Search for the answer or ask AI
• Try to implement the answer
• Repeat until the project is complete
• If you can't find the answer, ask an expert

A few years ago, Google searching was a skill.

Whether you're learning Photoshop or learning to program, start with what you know.

At least try to take the first step. Download the software and start playing around. Try to create something. Anything.

Just get your mind in a state where it's hungry to learn.

3) Start With What You Know

Learning comes from struggle, not memorization.

Start the project. No, don't watch 20 tutorials beforehand. Let it expose the gaps in your knowledge. Try to figure it out. Search for the answer when your mind is most likely to remember it.

A project narrows your mind further.

It optimizes pattern recognition further.

When I want to learn something new, I don't start learning first.
I outline a project first.

Then I learn exactly what I need and build out the project while learning.

That way, you only learn what you need, and don't waste months of time wasting info

Pattern recognition.

1) Map Out Your Ideal Life

Most people don't have an aim for their learning.

They learn what they're told to learn or what their parents or idols will approve of them learning.

People learn themselves into a life they hate, or they just start to hate learning like they did in

Learning is a meta skill.

The skill of all skills.

Because if you can learn faster, you can achieve success that much faster.

Learning, for most people, has become a form of mental masturbation, consuming information just so they feel like they're learning something.

The most important thing you can do when the world is changing rapidly is learn.

Here's how to learn anything 10x faster than anyone:

Think bigger.

Because that alone will open your mind to possibilities you didn't even know existed. Your choices shift in a way that start getting results. Big or small.

You can limit yourself and say you don't want to achieve big things, but that only guarantees that you wont.

Learn a lot of stuff. Build a lot of stuff. Identify problems. Solve them. Discover new paths. Take them. Reflect on the journey. Do it better the next time. Stay aware of distractions. Don't turn on autopilot. Take risks. Make mistakes. Fail, hard. Bounce back. Win.

That's it.

Maturity is discovering that most of your life is spent in a plateau, and if you don't fall in love with practice, mastery, and moving the needle forward you'll constantly try to escape the plateau with cheap stimulation and busy work that only keeps you there longer.

The best skill you can learn is how to learn.

Because the faster you learn the skills that allow you to achieve what you're trying to achieve, the faster you achieve it.

Here's how to learn 10x faster than anyone:
https://t.co/H2vcTjzFSs

Fill your mind with books, learning, and socializing.

Use your mind with creativity, focus, and meaningful work.

Clear your mind with rest, silence, and self-reflection.

Most people fill. Less use. Few clear.
I've started writing down every single thing that could go wrong when I start something new and it's insane how much clarity it brings.
Your life changes when you realize that failure isn't something to avoid, but the only way to learn in a way that is tailored to you.

Success is mostly an internal battle between your lower self and higher self.

That's why most people fail at anything they try.

They don't have a strategy, and they don't know how to deal with psychological issues that prevent them from making progress:

The reason people don't achieve big goals is because they don't realize that the only source of truth is making mistakes. They soak up advice and theory, expecting it to be an exact match to their mind, experience, and situation just to fail once and give up completely.

Normalize ignoring trends and hype that don't align with your goals. Those are the literal definition of a distraction. And if you don't have goals (that you chose to pursue, not ones assigned to you) you are by definition always distracted.
